conclusion: To determine the pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K, we need to analyze the given p-T and V-T graphs.
The p-T graph is a straight line passing through the origin, indicating that the pressure is directly proportional to the temperature.
This is consistent with Charles's Law, which states p ∝ T for a fixed amount of gas at constant volume.
The points on the p-T graph are (200 K, 0.5 × 10^5 Pa) and (400 K, 1.0 × 10^5 Pa).
The slope of the p-T line is calculated as slope = Δp / ΔT = (1.0 × 10^5 Pa - 0.5 × 10^5 Pa) / (400 K - 200 K) = 2500 Pa/K.
The equation of the p-T line is determined to be p = 2500 Pa/K × T.
The V-T graph shows a horizontal line for temperatures between 400 K and 600 K, indicating that the volume is constant.
This is consistent with Charles's Law, which states V ∝ T for a fixed amount of gas at constant pressure.
The volume is constant at V = 2.5 m^3 for temperatures between 400 K and 600 K.
Using the equation p = 2500 Pa/K × T, substituting T = 600 K gives p = 2500 Pa/K × 600 K = 1.5 × 10^6 Pa.
The pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K is 1.5 × 10^5 Pa.
